metadata.description: Proof-of-concept, cross-lingual dataset for the Bonepoke Protocol. Stories include short descriptive excerpts (~3,000 words max) in original language (if non-English) and English translation. Symbolic traces and example metrics (β and E) are provided for each.
metadata.note: Original stories are from public domain sources (primarily Project Gutenberg and other public domain translations). Traces generated by GPT-5-mini on 2025-10-08.

stories.title: The Yellow Wallpaper
stories.author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
stories.text_original: Excerpt from Project Gutenberg edition, depicting a woman confined to a room with a disturbing wallpaper.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: Bonepoke urges contradiction: the narrator is constrained, yet the wallpaper reflects hidden freedom; tension rises as mental structures resist smoothing.

stories.title: The Monkey's Paw
stories.author: W.W. Jacobs
stories.text_original: Excerpt from Project Gutenberg edition, presenting a magical paw with dangerous wishes.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: High β in wishes vs. consequences; Bonepoke preserves moral irony and foreshadowing tension.

stories.title: The Lottery
stories.author: Shirley Jackson
stories.text_original: Excerpt from Project Gutenberg edition, describing a small town's unsettling ritual.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: Ritual tension maintained; Bonepoke preserves societal contradiction without lexical exhaustion.

stories.title: The Bet
stories.author: Anton Chekhov
stories.text_original: Excerpt from original Russian text, depicting a banker and a lawyer making a high-stakes wager.
stories.text_english: English translation excerpt: a banker and a lawyer make a bet over the morality of life imprisonment.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: High β from moral tension and confinement; narrative resists smoothing ethical ambiguity.
stories.symbolic_trace_english: High β preserved; English translation maintains moral tension and structural conflict.

stories.title: The Lady with the Dog
stories.author: Anton Chekhov
stories.text_original: Excerpt from original Russian text: a man meets a married woman in Yalta, starting a complex relationship.
stories.text_english: English translation excerpt: a man and a married woman begin a morally complicated affair in Yalta.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: Structural tension from forbidden romance; narrative avoids smoothing internal conflict.
stories.symbolic_trace_english: β maintained; translation preserves romantic and moral tension.

stories.title: The Open Window
stories.author: Saki
stories.text_original: Excerpt from Project Gutenberg edition, showing a clever deception played on a visitor.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: High β in deception vs. perception; smoothing suppressed to preserve narrative trick.

stories.title: The Nose
stories.author: Nikolai Gogol
stories.text_original: Excerpt from original Russian text, a bureaucrat loses his nose, which develops a life of its own.
stories.text_english: English translation excerpt: a man wakes to find his nose missing and acting independently.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: Absurd tension and social contradiction; narrative refuses smoothing.
stories.symbolic_trace_english: High β preserved; translation maintains absurdity and social tension.

stories.title: The Lady, or the Tiger?
stories.author: Frank R. Stockton
stories.text_original: Excerpt from Project Gutenberg edition, presenting a story with an ambiguous ending.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: Ambiguous ending preserves tension; high β maintained, smoothing resisted.

stories.title: The Story of an Hour
stories.author: Kate Chopin
stories.text_original: Excerpt from Project Gutenberg edition, exploring a woman’s complex emotions upon learning of her husband's death.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: Emotional contradiction between freedom and mortality; tension preserved, smoothing resisted.

stories.title: The Necklace
stories.author: Guy de Maupassant
stories.text_original: Excerpt from original French text: a woman borrows a necklace to appear wealthy, leading to irony and misfortune.
stories.text_english: English translation excerpt: a woman borrows jewelry to impress society, experiencing ironic consequences.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: Irony-driven tension; narrative refuses to smooth social and moral consequences.
stories.symbolic_trace_english: β preserved; translation keeps ironic tension intact.

stories.title: The Open Boat
stories.author: Stephen Crane
stories.text_original: Excerpt from Project Gutenberg edition, depicting men struggling against natural forces at sea.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: Existential tension preserved; Bonepoke resists smoothing natural forces vs. human struggle.

stories.title: The Secret Life of Walter Mitty
stories.author: James Thurber
stories.text_original: Excerpt from Project Gutenberg edition, following a daydreaming man through mundane life.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: Fantasy vs. mundane reality generates structural tension; narrative smoothing suppressed.

stories.title: The Sniper
stories.author: Liam O'Flaherty
stories.text_original: Excerpt from Project Gutenberg edition, focusing on a soldier in a high-stress urban conflict.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: Conflict tension preserved; high β maintained between duty and moral reflection.

stories.title: The Interlopers
stories.author: Saki
stories.text_original: Excerpt from Project Gutenberg edition, portraying a family feud and sudden reversal of fortune.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: Feud and sudden reversal create β; smoothing suppressed to preserve narrative shock.

stories.title: The Adventure of the Engineer's Thumb
stories.author: Arthur Conan Doyle
stories.text_original: Excerpt from Project Gutenberg edition, following an engineer encountering unexpected peril.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: Contradiction arises between procedural logic and unexpected peril; narrative tension is retained without lexical flattening.

stories.title: The Cask of Amontillado
stories.author: Edgar Allan Poe
stories.text_original: Excerpt from Project Gutenberg edition, illustrating revenge and dark irony within a confined catacomb.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: Dark irony and revenge generate β; narrative refuses to smooth moral tension, preserving high structural strain.

stories.title: The Fall of the House of Usher
stories.author: Edgar Allan Poe
stories.text_original: Excerpt from Project Gutenberg edition, describing a decaying mansion and the mental decline of its inhabitants.
stories.symbolic_trace_original: Bonepoke identifies high-β horror elements; mental decay vs. architectural collapse maintains tension without lexical exhaustion.
